text: Harold Warren Furman II, "Hal" (born June 2, 1955) is an American businessman and a former U.S. government official. He co-founded and serves as the chairman and managing director of The Furman Group, a water infrastructure consulting firm based in Washington, D.C.http://thehill.com/business-a- lobbying/lobbying-hires/372645-lobbying-world In 1994, Furman ran for the United States Senate from Nevada. Our Campaigns While he won the crowded Republican primary, he lost the general election to the incumbent Senator, Richard Bryan.Driggs, Don. Nevada Politics & Government: Conservatism in an Open Society. U of Nebraska Press: 1996.https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/06/us/nevada-girds-for-primary-vote.html ==Education== Furman graduated from The University of Southern California with a degree in Political Science, and then went on to get his Juris Doctor from the University of Southern California Law Center. After graduating and passing the State Bar of Nevada, he briefly practiced law in Reno, Nevada with Woodburn, Wedge, Blakey, & Jeppson. ==Government work== In 1981, Furman became Legislative Counsel to the United States Senator Paul Laxalt (R-NV); he then went on to become Special Counsel to the Commissioner of the United States Bureau of Reclamation, and in 1983, President Ronald Reagan appointed Furman as the Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary for Water and Science. In that capacity, he oversaw the U.S. Geological Survey, the Bureau of Mines, and the Bureau of Reclamation.Sinclair, Ward. Water Fight; California Farmers Persuade Interior To Join Effort to Change Irrigation Law. The Washington Post. August 28, 1983. He served as the principal water policy advisor to three Secretaries of the Interior: James G. Watt, William P. Clark, and Donald P. Hodel. New Water Supply Coalition During his tenure at the Interior Department, Furman worked to negotiate technical assistance agreements involving the reconstruction of the power plant at the Aswan Dam in Egypt and another involving the Three Gorges Dam in the People's Republic of China.http://www.usbr.gov/history/OralHistories/GUY,SAMMIED.pdf In recognition of his work on the latter agreement, Engineering News-Record named Furman one of its People of the Year in 1985.https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Furman_ENR_Award.jpg After leaving government service, Furman became a partner in the Washington, D.C. office of Heron, Burchette, Ruckert, & Rothwell working on behalf of clients that were building water infrastructure projects. While in government and shortly thereafter, he often was asked to testify before Congressional hearings on water issues.http://www.c-span.org/person/?halfurman ==Business work== Hal Furman speaking on behalf of the New Water Supply Coalition New Water Supply Coalition Furman is the chairman and managing director of The Furman Group, which he founded in 1992.http://www.politico.com/politicoinfluence/0314/politicoinfluence13391.html He advises clients in the area of water and sanitation on government affairs and specialized consulting services. Additionally, he heads Balboa Resources, Inc, which provides project consulting services to clients domestically and abroad in the area of water infrastructure development and public-private partnerships. Balboa Resources Furman is a specialist in designing financing solutions involving both government and private financing for water and sanitation projects. In 1992, while representing several large southern California water agencies, he worked with the United States Congress and to create the Bureau of Reclamation Title XVI Program to encourage the development of water recycling and reuse projects. US Board of Reclamation Title XVISarasohn, Judy. States Ask Feds to Help Get the Salt Out. The Washington Post. April 13, 2003 He later served as the executive director of the New Water Supply Coalition, an advocacy group consisting of some of the Nation's largest water utilities. The New Water Supply Coalition advocated the use of tax credit bonds to assist in the financing of qualified water supply projects. The concept was later incorporated into the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 as "Build America Bonds." New Group Seeks Tax Credit Bonds for Desalination, Water Recycling ==Politics == In 1994, Furman was the Republican nominee for the United States Senate in Nevada.https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/07/us/nevada-governor-wins.html He captured the party's nomination with 50% of the vote against a crowded field, but lost the general election to the incumbent Senator, Richard Bryan. Nevada Governor Wins Democratic Primary in Landslide with PM-Nevada Primary – Glancehttp://archive.nevadajournal.com/nj97/01/why.htm Las Vegas Sun Article In 1996, Furman chaired Senator Robert Dole's Presidential campaign in Nevada. He was a delegate to the GOP Convention in San Diego and served on the Platform Committee. In 2000 and 2008, Furman served on the National Finance Committee for Senator John McCain's two Presidential campaigns. In 2008, he was a delegate to the Republican Convention in Minneapolis-St. Paul.
